questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and painful swelling of her right knee for 3 weeks. She works as a professional ballet dancer and says, “I'm always trying to be in shape for my upcoming performances.” She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (99 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Physical examination shows tenderness and limited range of motion in her right knee. Oral examination shows bleeding and swelling of the gums. There are diffuse petechiae around hair follicles on her abdomen and both thighs. Laboratory studies show a prothrombin time of 12 seconds, an activated partial thromboplastin time of 35 seconds, and a bleeding time of 11 minutes (N = 2–7). Arthrocentesis of the right knee shows bloody synovial fluid. The patient’s condition is most likely associated with a defect in a reaction that occurs in which of the following cellular structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The lysosome is the site at which macromolecules (e.g., misfolded proteins, cell debris) are degraded; it is not involved in collagen synthesis. Defects in lysosome function occur in lysosomal storage diseases, whereas this patient's symptoms are characteristic of scurvy.

B) INCORRECT:

The final modification and packaging of the procollagen triple helix into transport vesicles are the last steps prior to its secretion into the extracellular space (i.e., exocytosis) and take place in the Golgi apparatus. These processes do not require vitamin C.
Image Description:

The Golgi apparatus is composed of cisternae, which are arranged in a convex cis or a concave trans face. The cis face receives transport vesicles from transitional ER (1). These contain cargo proteins as well as other proteins of the ER, which are sent back to the transitional ER. Cargo proteins are further transported from one cistern to the other and are modified (e.g., glycosylated) during the process (2). At the trans face, vesicles detach and reach the cell membrane, where they fuse together. Through fusion, membrane proteins (3) or secretory proteins (4) are transported to their destination. Other vesicles contain acidic enzymes labeled with mannose-6-phosphate and are detached from the Golgi apparatus by the protein clathrin in order to form primary lysosomes (5).

C) CORRECT:

Hydroxylation of lysine and proline residues in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of fibroblasts is an essential step in collagen synthesis, as hydroxylysine-lysine cross-links between tropocollagen molecules are needed in order to form firm collagen fibrils. This reaction is catalyzed by prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase and requires vitamin C as a cofactor. Consequently, vitamin C deficiency, as seen in this patient, reduces the tensile strength of collagen and results in typical manifestations of scurvy, which include bleeding diathesis due to weakened vessel walls (potentially leading to hemarthrosis and mucosal bleeding), delayed wound healing, swollen gums, perifollicular petechiae, a weakened immune response, and fatigue (due to anemia).
Image Description:

Collagen biosynthesis starts with the translation (1) at the rough ER, during which the polypeptide chain of the collagens is modified (Hydroxylation, 2). For attaching the OH groups, vitamin C is necessary as a cofactor for lysyl hydroxylase and prolyl hydroxylase. Next, by attaching sugar molecules, hydroxylysine residues are glycosylated (3). Three procollagen chains form a triple helix (4). These very large molecules are enclosed in vesicles, transported to the cell membrane via the Golgi apparatus and secreted via exocytosis in the extracellular space (5). At this stage, the collagen triple helix is further processed: The propeptides at the end of the collagen propeptide chains are split off (6). Next, the formed tropocollagens are cross-linked to fibrils (fibrillogenesis, 7). In the extracellular space, several of these fibrils form collagen fibers (8).

Various conditions are the result of defective collagen synthesis. Examples can be found in the overlay.

D) INCORRECT:

The transcription of collagen DNA to mRNA is the first step in collagen synthesis and takes place in the nucleus of fibroblasts. This process is mainly mediated by RNA polymerase II and does not require vitamin C.

E) INCORRECT:

The extracellular space is the site of tropocollagen formation, cross-linking, and collagen fiber formation. Following its secretion into the extracellular space, the procollagen triple helix is cleaved at the C-terminus and N-terminus to form water-insoluble tropocollagen. Adjacent tropocollagen molecules are reinforced through the cross-linking of hydroxylysine residues (catalyzed by copper-dependent lysyl oxidase) to form collagen fibrils. Finally, several collagen fibrils accumulate to form collagen fibers. Vitamin C does not play a role in any of the steps taking place in the extracellular space.

F) INCORRECT:

Free ribosomes float within the cytosol and are the site of synthesis of intracellular proteins (cytosolic, nuclear, and mitochondrial proteins). However, collagen is a secreted protein and is therefore translated by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum (site of synthesis of secretory proteins) instead. Vitamin C does not play a role in the translation step of collagen synthesis.
questions.hint: This underweight patient's hemarthrosis, perifollicular petechiae, and bleeding gums are likely due to impaired collagen synthesis secondary to vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) from malnutrition.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent headaches over the past 2 months and partial blindness that started this morning. An MRI of the head shows a 3-cm partially calcified cystic mass located in the suprasellar space. A biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of craniopharyngioma. Further evaluation with quantitative assays shows increased activity of RNA polymerase I. Activity of this enzyme is highest in which of the following areas in the schematic diagram of a cell?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitochondria possess their own DNA (mtDNA) and therefore produce specific mitochondrial mRNA, tRNA, and rRNA. Transcription of mtDNA to mtRNA and translation of mtRNA to mitochondrial proteins are both catalyzed by the mitochondrial RNA polymerase, not by RNA polymerase I.

B) CORRECT:

The nucleolus is a substructure of the nucleus and is only found in eukaryotic cells. RNA polymerase I is exclusively present in the nucleolus, where it performs rRNA transcription. RNA polymerase I catalyzes transcription of 5.8S, 18S, and 28S rRNA. The only rRNA type that is not transcribed by RNA polymerase I (and the only rRNA type that is transcribed outside the nucleolus) is 5S rRNA, which is transcribed by RNA polymerase III.

C) INCORRECT:

The rough endoplasmic reticulum wall is studded with ribosomes, which carry out protein synthesis (translation). Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits does not take place in the rough ER and it does not contain RNA polymerase I.

D) INCORRECT:

Lysosomes contain a variety of enzymes that are responsible for the hydrolysis of intracellular and extracellular compounds. Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits do not take place in the lysosomes, and they do not contain RNA polymerase I.

E) INCORRECT:

The smooth endoplasmic reticulum is involved in the synthesis of new cellular membrane as well as in various catabolic and anabolic pathways (e.g., lipid synthesis). Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits do not take place in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, and it does not contain RNA polymerase I.

F) INCORRECT:

The nucleus contains the genetic information of a cell (except for mitochondrial DNA). Its nucleoplasm contains RNA polymerases II and III but not RNA polymerase I. Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits do not take place in the nucleus.

G) INCORRECT:

The cell membrane is a lipid bilayer that separates the interior of the cell from the environment. Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits does not take place in the cell membrane, and it does not contain RNA polymerase I.

H) INCORRECT:

The Golgi apparatus mediates transport of proteins and lipids within the cell and contains various enzymes that are responsible for the modification of those compounds (e.g., phosphorylases). Transcription of rRNA and assembly of ribosomal subunits does not take place in the Golgi apparatus, and it does not contain RNA polymerase I.
questions.hint: In eukaryotic cells, RNA polymerase I is responsible for the transcription of ribosomal RNA (rRNA), which accounts for the majority of total RNA synthesized in a cell.

questions.text: An investigator is studying membranous transport proteins in the kidneys of an experimental animal. The animal lacks a hormone which normally leads to integration of a transmembrane protein in the principal cells of the collecting ducts. The animal has excessive thirst and highly diluted urine. When a synthetic analogue of the missing hormone is given, water transport across the plasma membranes of the principal cells increases, and the animal produces more concentrated urine. The membranous transport mechanism underlying the increase of water reabsorption into the principal cells most resembles which of the following processes?

choices.text: Reabsorption of glucose by renal tubular cells
Secretion of doxorubicin from dysplastic colonic cells
Uptake of fructose by small intestinal enterocytes
Removal of calcium from cardiac myocytes
Absorption of LDL cholesterol by hepatocytes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reabsorption of glucose by renal tubular cells is performed by sodium-dependent glucose cotransporter 1 (SGLT1) and 2 (SGLT2). These proteins are symporters, which import glucose and sodium from the proximal convoluted tubule into the cell. SGLT1 and SGLT2 use the high extracellular sodium concentration created by Na+/K+-ATPase to drive the reabsorption of glucose against its concentration gradient. This is an example of secondary active transport rather than facilitated diffusion.

B) INCORRECT:

Secretion of doxorubicin from dysplastic colonic cells can occur as a reaction to doxorubicin exposure. Multidrug resistance protein 1 (MDR1), an ATP-dependent pump expressed by dysplastic cells, achieves this by actively transporting doxorubicin up a concentration gradient. This is an example of primary active transport rather than facilitated diffusion.

C) CORRECT:

Uptake of fructose by small intestine enterocytes is achieved via the glucose transporter 5 (GLUT-5) membrane transport protein. GLUT-5 is a uniporter that facilitates the movement of fructose from high concentrations in the intestinal lumen to lower concentrations in the intracellular compartment. This mechanism, like AQP2, uses a specific transport protein that is not ATP-dependent and is therefore also an example of facilitated diffusion. Other examples of facilitated diffusion via carrier proteins include cellular glucose uptake via other types of transmembrane glucose transporters (e.g., GLUT-2 in the pancreas), bicarbonate reabsorption in the early proximal convoluted tubule, and urea reabsorption in the inner collecting ducts.

Facilitated diffusion can take place either through carrier proteins or gated channels. Carrier proteins undergo a transformational change after substrate binding to enable transport across a membrane, whereas gated channels form pores to allow free diffusion. Calcium transport from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytosol is facilitated by voltage-gated calcium channels.

D) INCORRECT:

Removal of calcium from cardiac myocytes is achieved by a type of membrane transport protein called Na+/Ca2+ exchangers. These membrane transport proteins function as antiporters, importing sodium down a concentration gradient in exchange for exporting calcium up a concentration gradient. This is an example of secondary active transport rather than facilitated diffusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Absorption of LDL cholesterol by hepatocytes is achieved via receptor-mediated endocytosis that is triggered by LDL binding. Unlike AQPT2, which facilitates diffusion down a concentration gradient, LDL endocytosis transports molecules up a concentration gradient. Endocytosis is not an example of facilitated diffusion.
questions.hint: The experimental animal lacks antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which acts on V2 receptors. Activation of these receptors results in the integration of aquaporin-2 channels (AQP2) in principal cells in the collecting tubules of the kidney. This membrane integration of AQP2 increases water permeability and subsequent reabsorption along an osmotic gradient, a process referred to as facilitated diffusion.

questions.text: A 93-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after his daughter found him lying unresponsive in his bed. His medical history is unknown. The man is declared dead on arrival and an autopsy is conducted, as requested by his family. Microscopic examination of the heart shows cardiac myocytes with intracellular yellow-brown pigmented granular deposits. Similar granular deposits are also seen in hepatocytes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these histological findings?

choices.text: Disorganized type I and III collagen growth

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intracellular accumulation of unbound copper is characteristic of Wilson disease, which can manifest with green-brown pigments on the peripheral iris (Kayser-Fleischer rings) and jaundice. However, histopathological examination of organs affected by Wilson disease would show fatty infiltration, nuclear glycogen inclusions, fibrosis, and positive copper-staining. The presence of yellow-brown pigmented granules, as seen in this patient, is due to a different mechanism.

B) INCORRECT:

The deposition of abnormal insoluble proteins (e.g., β-pleated sheets, insoluble fibrils) is the mechanism behind the organ dysfunction seen with amyloidosis. Amyloid proteins can be found in many different organs, including the heart and liver, as are involved here as well. However, histopathological examination would show amorphous, eosinophilic interstitial depositions in tissues rather than the yellow-brown pigmented granules as seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Lipofuscin is composed of yellow-brown pigmented granules, also known as wear-and-tear pigments, which are associated with normal aging. These granules are formed by the oxidation of lysosomal contents and can be found in various organs (e.g., heart, liver, kidneys). Two principal explanations are suggested for the increased formation of lipofuscin with age. First, lipofuscin is never totally eliminated, not even at a young age; thus, it accumulates in cells over time. Second, various age-related mechanisms can cause a buildup of lipofuscin, including the enhancement of autophagocytosis, a decline in intralysosomal degradation, and/or a decrease in exocytosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cardiac myocytes (H&E stain; 100x magnification)

Lipofuscin (green overlay) is visible as fine, yellow-brown granules in the perinuclear region of the central cardiac myocyte.

The finding of lipofuscin usually indicates the physiological aging of cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Free radical cell damage results from exposure to reactive oxygen species, which can occur as a result of various toxic insults including cancer chemotherapeutics, reperfusion injury, and acetaminophen toxicity. However, histopathologic examination of tissue affected by free radical cell damage would typically show necrosis, rather than yellow-brown pigment granules as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Disorganized type I and type III collagen growth is the mechanism behind keloid scarring, which commonly occurs following a local trauma and/or surgery. However, histopathological examination of keloid tissue would show disorganized aggregates of type I and type III collagen rather than the presence of yellow-brown pigmented granules seen in this patient. Furthermore, keloid formation does not occur in cardiac or liver parenchyma.
questions.hint: Considering the age of this patient, a significant amount of age-related changes are expected. The yellow-brown granules described here refer to lipofuscin.

questions.text: An investigator is studying neuronal regeneration. For microscopic visualization of the neuron, an aniline stain is applied. After staining, only the soma and dendrites of the neurons are visualized, not the axon. Presence of which of the following cellular elements best explains this staining pattern?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitochondria are involved in many cellular processes but primarily function to generate energy. Mitochondria are composed of a complex double membrane with transmembrane proteins. However, they are not rich in basophilic RNA and thus do not have a high affinity for the Nissl stain. Furthermore, mitochondria are distributed throughout the neuron and would also be seen in the axon, unlike the staining pattern described.

B) INCORRECT:

Microtubules are components of the cytoskeleton which reinforce the cell's shape and stability and, in some cases, facilitate motion. Microtubules are found in all parts of the neuron, including the axon where they are involved in axonal transport. Thus, the staining pattern described, which excludes the axons, cannot be explained by microtubules.

C) INCORRECT:

The nucleus is a double-membraned organelle that functions to replicate and transcribe DNA. Although DNA is basophilic and has some affinity for the Nissl stain, the nucleus is a single organelle and is not distributed throughout the soma and dendrites. Thus, binding of the Nissl stain to the nucleus does not explain the staining pattern described.

D) INCORRECT:

Lysosomes contain digestive enzymes and are primarily responsible for cellular waste removal. Lysosomes are not found in the axon but are also not rich in basophilic RNA and thus, do not have a high affinity for the Nissl stain.

E) INCORRECT:

The Golgi apparatus is a disc-shaped vesicle system that is involved in the post-translational modification and packaging of products for export out of the cell. It is found in the soma and dendrites, and not in the axon. The Golgi apparatus is not rich in basophilic RNA and thus would not have a high affinity for the Nissl stain.

F) CORRECT:

The rough endoplasmic reticulum (rough ER) is an organelle involved in protein synthesis. The surface of the rough ER is covered with ribosomes and the ribosomes' RNA subunits are basophilic, which means that they have a high affinity for the Nissl stain. Since the rough ER is located only in the soma and dendrites, these regions are visualized with Nissl stain while the axon is not.
questions.hint: The stain described is the Nissl stain (cresyl violet).

questions.text: An investigator is studying the efficiency of a new anti-gout drug in comparison to colchicine in an experimental animal model. The test group of animals is injected with the new drug, while the control group receives injections of colchicine. Which of the following cellular functions will most likely be impaired in the control subjects after the injection?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stereocilia are non-motile membrane protrusions formed by dense, cross-linked bundles of actin filaments. Stereocilia are found in the inner ear, where they enable mechanosensing of sounds and help with balance, as well as in the epididymis and the ductus deferens, where they facilitate absorption of fluid. Since colchicine interferes with the formation of microtubules rather than actin filaments, it would not impair function of the stereocilia.

B) INCORRECT:

Muscle contractions are caused by actin and myosin filaments sliding along each other. Although colchicine does interfere with the cytoskeleton, it inhibits the formation of microtubules rather than actin filaments and would therefore not impair muscle contraction.
Image Description:

Smooth muscles cells are spindle-shaped, have a single nucleus, and contain numerous invaginations in the sarcolemma (caveolae). Because of the irregular arrangement of myofilaments (actin and myosin) in the cell, smooth muscles cells lack sarcomeres (in contrast to striated muscle). Actin filaments are anchored by dense bodies and dense bands, which are linked together by intermediate filaments. Myosin filaments of smooth muscle have an antiparallel arrangement, with the upper and lower rows of myosin heads facing different directions. This allows strong traction to be exerted on the actin filaments (direction of tension indicated by the arrows).

C) INCORRECT:

Nutrient absorption by enterocytes of the small intestine is facilitated by microvilli, as they increase the cell's surface area. Microvilli are finger-like cell membrane protrusions formed by dense, cross-linked bundles of actin filaments. Since colchicine interferes with the formation of microtubules rather than actin filaments, it would not impair nutrient absorption in the body.

D) CORRECT:

Axonal transport is dependent on the polymerization of microtubules; colchicine inhibits this process by binding tubulin in its monomeric form. As a result, microtubule-associated motor proteins (i.e., kinesin and dynein) that transport substances such as synaptic vesicles cannot move along the microtubules. Loss of axonal functions is responsible for the neuromyopathic side effects of colchicine. Microtubule function is also important for cell migration, formation of the spindle apparatus during cell division, and motion of kinocilia and flagella.
Image Description:

In microtubule polymerization, GTP-tubulin dimers (each made up of an α-tubulin and a β-tubulin) accumulate at the plus end. The GTP of β-tubulin spontaneously hydrolyzes shortly afterwards, leading to loss of microtubule stability. Microtubules do not depolymerize if GTP-tubulin dimers are present at the plus end.

The minus end is usually located in the centrosome of the cell, the microtubule organizing center, where it is stabilized by γ-tubulin and capping proteins. In principle, tubulin dimers could also accumulate at the minus end; however, attachment would be very slow (e.g., when a microtubule breaks).

E) INCORRECT:

Transmembrane signal transduction allows an extracellular ligand to exert an effect within the cell. Although the cytoskeleton is thought to play an important role in regulating cell signaling and protein interactions, this function is attributed to a modulation of actin filaments. Colchicine, however, disrupts the function of microtubules and is not known to affect transmembrane signaling.

F) INCORRECT:

Intercellular adhesion allows cells to connect and interact with neighboring cells via cell adhesion molecules (CAMs). These CAMs form complexes on the cell surface (e.g., desmosomes, tight junctions, gap junctions) that are anchored in the cytoskeleton of either cell via actin or intermediate filaments. However, colchicine disrupts the formation of microtubules rather than actin or intermediate filaments, and would therefore not affect intercellular adhesion.
Image Description:

Cell junctions are points of cell-cell or cell-extracellular matrix contact most abundantly found between epithelial cells. There are three major classes of cell junctions:

1. Tight junctions are occluding junctions that close the gaps between epithelial cells and act as a diffusion barrier. They are typically found at the apical aspect of cells.

2. Anchoring junctions are mechanical connections between cells. Based on the anchoring structures and the type of connection, they are divided into:
- Zonula adherens: form cell-cell junctions via actin filaments
- Desmosomes: form cell-cell junctions via intermediate filaments
- Hemidesmosomes: anchor cells to the basement membrane (i.e., cell-extracellular matrix junction) via intermediate filaments and integrins

3. Gap junctions or communicating junctions are intercellular channels that allow the passage of ions and molecules between cells.
questions.hint: Colchicine is an inhibitor of microtubule polymerization.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with inoperable esophageal carcinoma undergoes palliative chemoradiotherapy. Four hours after his first infusion of carboplatin and paclitaxel, he develops nausea and 3 episodes of vomiting and dry heaving. This adverse reaction is caused by stimulation of a brain region on the floor of the fourth ventricle. Chemotherapeutic drugs are able to stimulate this region because of the absence of a cell junction that is composed of which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Integrins are transmembrane receptor proteins that mediate cell adhesion to basement membranes and establish intercellular junctions in the immune system (e.g., for leukocyte extravasation). These proteins are not components of tight junctions.

B) CORRECT:

Claudins and occludins are key components of the tight junctions that form the blood-brain barrier. The tight junctions seal adjacent epithelial cells together, which prevents paracellular transport of ions and molecules. The chemoreceptor trigger zone lacks tight junctions and is thus highly permeable. As a result, several chemotherapeutic drugs can freely cross the blood-brain barrier and cause nausea.

The chemoreceptor trigger zone of the area postrema responds to signaling from muscarinic (M1), dopaminergic (D2), histaminic (H1), serotoninergic (5-HT3), and neurokininergic (NK-1) receptors. Therefore, 5-HT3 antagonists (e.g., ondansetron), D2 antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide), and NK-1 antagonists (e.g., aprepitant) are commonly used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea.
Image Description:

The different cell junction types differ in their molecular structure; however, they all contain certain types of transmembrane proteins. The transmembrane proteins of the zonula adhaerens, desmosomes, and hemidesmosomes are connected to a component of the cytoskeleton, but also to structures external to the cell. The tight junction proteins claudin and occludin are linked to actin filaments of the cytoskeleton by additional proteins (not shown). Their extracellular domains interact with one another and close the gaps between epithelial cells. Gap junctions are similar to ion channels in that they are permeable to small molecules and alternate between open and closed states. In addition to their communication function, gap junctions support the adhesion of neighboring cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Cadherins and catenins are key components of adherens junctions, which connect adjacent cells together in a continuous, belt-like manner (e.g., in epithelial and endothelial tissues). These proteins are not components of tight junctions.

D) INCORRECT:

Connexins are transmembrane proteins that assemble to form connexons, which then form gap junctions. These channels permit the passage of electrical or chemical signals between neighboring cells (e.g., to propagate the cardiac action potential). These proteins are not components of tight junctions.

E) INCORRECT:

Desmogleins and desmocollins are structural proteins within desmosomes that promote cell-to-cell adhesion. These proteins are not components of tight junctions.
questions.hint: The brain region on the floor of the fourth ventricle is the chemoreceptor trigger zone, which is located within the area postrema. The lack of tight junctions in this zone, which normally form the blood-brain barrier, makes it vulnerable to emetic stimuli (e.g., chemotherapeutic drugs).

questions.text: An investigator is studying the recycling of heme proteins in various cell types. Heat denaturation and high-performance liquid chromatography are used to carry out and observe the selective destruction of hemoglobin molecules in red blood cells. It is found that these cells are unable to regenerate new heme molecules. A lack of which of the following structures is the most likely explanation for this observation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Golgi apparatus acts as the coordination center of membrane vesicle trafficking by labeling proteins and lipids for transport to specific areas within the cell (e.g., lysosomes, peroxisomes). The Golgi apparatus is not involved in the synthesis of heme.
Image Description:

The Golgi apparatus is composed of cisternae, which are arranged in a convex cis or a concave trans face. The cis face receives transport vesicles from transitional ER (1). These contain cargo proteins as well as other proteins of the ER, which are sent back to the transitional ER. Cargo proteins are further transported from one cistern to the other and are modified (e.g., glycosylated) during the process (2). At the trans face, vesicles detach and reach the cell membrane, where they fuse together. Through fusion, membrane proteins (3) or secretory proteins (4) are transported to their destination. Other vesicles contain acidic enzymes labeled with mannose-6-phosphate and are detached from the Golgi apparatus by the protein clathrin in order to form primary lysosomes (5).

B) CORRECT:

Heme is synthesized in the mitochondria and the cytosol of immature RBCs. Mitochondria are the site of the first and the final step of heme synthesis, involving aminolevulinate synthase and ferrochelatase, respectively. The absence of organelles in RBCs allows them to be maximally filled with hemoglobin and gives them their biconcave cell shape. Without mitochondria, though, RBCs are unable to regenerate new heme molecules or produce ATP from the oxygen they transport. Instead, RBCs produce ATP by glycolysis and lactic acid fermentation of the resulting pyruvate.
Image Description:

A mitochondrion (bottom left, cross section) and its most important functions: Mitochondria are cell organelles made up of a smooth outer membrane, an inner membrane with an increased surface area as a result of folds (cristae), and the matrix, which harbors mitochondrial DNA and ribosomes and is the site of numerous metabolic processes.

Upper left: One of the most important functions of the mitochondria is supplying energy through the electron transport chain, which is integrated into the inner mitochondrial membrane. The phospholipid cardiolipin enables the close arrangement of individual complexes of the electron transport chain.

Upper right: The outer membrane is rich in pores and therefore permeable to numerous substances, whereas the inner membrane can only be permeated via specific transporters.

Bottom right: Proteins must be unfolded before transport in and out of the mitochondrion. Translocases of the inner and outer membranes (TIM and TOM) transport unfolded proteins across the membranes.

C) INCORRECT:

The smooth endoplasmic reticulum is a site of lipid synthesis, calcium storage, and biotransformation in cells. In hepatocytes, for example, the heme-binding cytochrome P450 enzymes are primarily located in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum and function in the transformation of both endogenous and exogenous compounds. However, this organelle does not participate in the synthesis of heme.
Image Description:

The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) forms a broad, branching system of channels in the cell. It is surrounded by a membrane and is in contact with the nuclear envelope. There are two types of ER, which differ both histologically and functionally.

Rough ER (RER) is tightly packed with ribosomes and forms elongated lamellae. Noncytosolic proteins are synthesized in the RER, whereas cytosolic proteins are directly synthesized in the cytosol on free ribosomes, which partially assemble into polysomes.

Smooth ER (SER) extends across the cytosol with a lattice of sacs or tube-like structures. It also stores carbohydrates and calcium and synthesizes lipids and steroids.

D) INCORRECT:

The nucleus stores and protects the genetic information of the cell and is the site of initiation for protein synthesis, namely, through transcription. The absence of nuclei prevents RBCs from synthesizing the subunits of hemoglobin. However, the synthesis of heme itself is not directly inhibited by the lack of a nucleus, nor does it occur within the nucleus.
Image Description:

The nucleus is surrounded by a nuclear envelope, which consists of an inner and outer nuclear membrane. The inner nuclear membrane is covered by the nuclear lamina, a network of intermediate filaments (lamina) that acts as a support and separates the nuclear membrane from chromatin. The outer nuclear membrane gradually extends into the endoplasmic reticulum. The inner and outer nuclear membranes fuse at some points and form nuclear pores with the aid of large protein complexes. Chromatin is located in the nucleus (karyoplasm). It is present as two forms: euchromatin, which is loosely packaged and active, and heterochromatin, which is densely packaged and inactive. The nucleolus is also located in the karyoplasm and is not surrounded by a membrane. It synthesizes ribosomes and consists of proteins and ribosomal RNA.

E) INCORRECT:

Lysosomes are the cell's primary waste disposal system, which involves the degradation of materials within the cell. An absence of these organelles would result in RBCs being unable to degrade malfunctioning and damaged proteins. However, lysosomes are not involved in the synthesis of heme.
Image Description:

Substances taken up during endocytosis are initially delivered to the endosomes. These fuse with primary lysosomes (enzyme-rich vesicles, which are formed by detachment of the Golgi apparatus) to secondary lysosomes, where lysosomal enzymes start to degrade the ingested material. If complete degradation is possible, the products generated, e.g., glucose, proteins, and lipids, are transported to the cytosol for further use. The lysosome can also fuse again with endosomes or secondary lysosomes. If lysosomal enzymes are unable to degrade the material that has been taken up, these remain in the lysosome and accumulate to form telolysosomes. Telolysosomes are exocytosed by the cell or accumulate in the cytosol of older cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Peroxisomes function to degrade hydrogen peroxide and initiate beta oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids. Peroxisomes are also involved in the biosynthesis of various molecules, including steroids and bile acids. However, they do not participate in heme synthesis.
Image Description:

Peroxisomes are small, round organelles that are surrounded by a lipid bilayer and frequently have crystalline inclusions. They contain enzymes that oxidize amino acids and fatty acids. As a result, peroxide is formed, which is converted into water and oxygen by the enzyme catalase.
questions.hint: Two enzymatic reactions (via aminolevulinate synthase and ferrochelatase) required to form heme complexes occur within this organelle.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the interaction between epithelial cells and calcium ion concentration. When the calcium ion concentration available to a sample of epithelial tissue is decreased, an increased gap between adjacent epithelial cells is seen on electron microscopy. This observed decrease in cell adhesion is most likely due to an effect on which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Claudins, along with occludin, are involved in the formation of tight (or occluding) junctions. Tight junctions seal adjacent epithelial cells together and prevent paracellular movement of ions and molecules. However, they are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level.

B) CORRECT:

Cadherins (or calcium-dependent adhesion protein) are a family of cell adhesion molecules that contribute to the formation of adherens junctions, which connect the actin cytoskeletons of adjacent cells. A lack of calcium ions would cause a loss of cadherins, leading to an increased gap between epithelial cells. Cadherins are also major cell-cell adhesion molecules in tumors. During tumor progression, the loss or alteration of cadherin function causes disaggregation of cancer cells from primary tumors, promoting invasion and metastasis of tumor cells.
Image Description:

The different cell junction types differ in their molecular structure; however, they all contain certain types of transmembrane proteins. The transmembrane proteins of the zonula adhaerens, desmosomes, and hemidesmosomes are connected to a component of the cytoskeleton, but also to structures external to the cell. The tight junction proteins claudin and occludin are linked to actin filaments of the cytoskeleton by additional proteins (not shown). Their extracellular domains interact with one another and close the gaps between epithelial cells. Gap junctions are similar to ion channels in that they are permeable to small molecules and alternate between open and closed states. In addition to their communication function, gap junctions support the adhesion of neighboring cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Actin filaments are important parts of the cytoskeleton that are involved in adhesion, as they connect to cadherins and form adherens junctions. However, they are are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytokeratins are a family of intermediate filaments that interact to form desmosomes, which connect cells to one another. However, cytokeratin is not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level.

E) INCORRECT:

Connexons are channels with a central pore formed from six membrane-spanning proteins called connexins. Two neighboring connexons form a gap junction, which permits the passage of electrical and chemical signals between cells. However, they are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level. Moreover, connexons are not involved in cell adhesion.

F) INCORRECT:

Laminins are a major component of the basal lamina. They contribute to cell attachment and differentiation as well as cell shape and movement. They also help maintain tissue phenotype and promote tissue survival. However, they are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level.

G) INCORRECT:

Integrins are membrane proteins that bind to collagen, laminin, and fibronectin in the basement membrane, lending structural integrity to the basolateral membrane. However, they are not calcium-dependent and would not be affected by a decreased calcium level. Moreover, integrins are not involved in cell-cell adhesion.
questions.hint: Loss of this protein can promote metastasis of malignant cells.

questions.text: A 79-year-old homeless man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after being found unresponsive by the police. On arrival, he is apneic and there are no palpable pulses. Despite appropriate life-saving measures, he dies. Examination of the heart during autopsy shows normal ventricles with a sigmoid-shaped interventricular septum. A photomicrograph of a section of the heart obtained at autopsy is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for the structure indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of iron granules would be consistent with hemochromatosis, which can also affect the heart and also appear as brown, sarcoplasmic perinuclear granules. However, other characteristic findings consistent with hemochromatosis are absent, such as fibrosis and cardiomegaly due to restrictive or dilated cardiomyopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Clumping of defective mitochondria is seen in mitochondrial myopathy, a rare genetic disorder that mainly affects organs with a high energy requirement including the heart. However, examination of the heart would show ventricular hypertrophy and/or dilatation, not a sigmoid-shaped interventricular septum. Moreover, the histological examination would show subsarcolemmal and intermyofibrillar mitochondria accumulation rather than the yellow-brown perinuclear inclusions seen here.

The mitochondrial accumulation that is seen in mitochondrial myopathy stains red with Gomori Trichrome stain, hence the commonly used descriptive term “ragged red fibers”.

C) CORRECT:

Lipofuscin granules, also known as wear-and-tear granules, are composed of yellow-brown pigmented granules and occur as a natural process with age. They are formed by the oxidation of phospholipid molecules and can be found in various organs (e.g., heart, liver, kidneys). Lipofuscin accumulates with age because it is never completely eliminated. Age-related mechanisms that can accelerate the accumulation of lipofuscin include the enhancement of autophagocytosis, a decline in intralysosomal degradation, and/or a decrease in exocytosis. A sigmoid-shaped interventricular septum is also a (physiological) sign of aging.

D) INCORRECT:

Aggregation of alpha-synuclein leads to neuronal death and is seen in conditions such as Parkinson disease, MSA, and Lewy body dementia. These neurodegenerative disorders mainly affect the brain and not the heart, which is the organ involved in this patient. Moreover, histological examination with H&E staining would show eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasmic inclusions rather than the yellow-brown pigmented inclusions seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Deposition of wild-type transthyretin is seen in senile amyloidosis and mainly affects the myocardium in elderly patients. However, senile amyloidosis would manifest with cardiomegaly due to myocardial thickening, not with a sigmoid-shaped interventricular septum. Moreover, histological examination with H&E staining would show amyloid proteins, which appear as glassy, eosinophilic, homogeneous deposits, not yellow-brown perinuclear inclusions.
questions.hint: The yellow-brown perinuclear inclusions indicated by the arrow are lipofuscin granules.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of abnormal growth and skin abnormalities. His mother has also noticed that his eyes do not fully close when sleeping. He is at the 24th percentile for height, 17th percentile for weight, and 29th percentile for head circumference. Physical examination shows wrinkled skin, prominent veins on the scalp and extremities, and circumoral cyanosis. Genetic testing shows a point mutation in a gene that encodes for a scaffold protein of the inner nuclear membrane. The mutation causes a deformed and unstable nuclear membrane, which leads to premature aging. Which of the following is most likely to be the defective protein?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Desmin is an intermediate filament found in the cytoskeleton of all muscle cells (cardiac, skeletal, and smooth). Desmin stabilizes muscle cells by cross-linking myofibrils at the Z disc of sarcomeres. It is not found in the inner nuclear membrane and has no association with Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Nesprin (KASH protein) is a protein of the outer nuclear membrane. It is not found in the inner nuclear membrane and has no association with Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome. Nesprin and its equivalent of the inner nuclear membrane, SUN protein, provide a connection between the cytoplasmic skeleton and the nuclear interior.

C) INCORRECT:

Vimentin is an intermediate filament found in the cytoskeleton of mesenchymal cells (e.g., fibroblasts, endothelial cells, macrophages), where it facilitates mechanical stability, migration, and contraction. Vimentin is not found in the inner nuclear membrane and has no association with Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Dystrophin is found in muscle cells, where it functions as anchor protein between the sarcolemma and actin filaments of the subsarcolemmal cytoskeleton. It is not found in the inner nuclear membrane and has no association with Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Lamins are intermediate filaments and the main component of the nuclear lamina, which is a scaffold of the nuclear envelope that lies inside the inner nuclear membrane. In addition to providing mechanical stability, lamins are involved in various processes of the cell cycle, e.g., transcription, signal transduction, and chromatin organization.

Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the gene encoding for lamin A. This mutation results in an unstable nuclear envelope with subsequent cell damage and death, as well as altered gene expression.
Image Description:

The nucleus is surrounded by a nuclear envelope, which consists of an inner and outer nuclear membrane. The inner nuclear membrane is covered by the nuclear lamina, a network of intermediate filaments (lamina) that acts as a support and separates the nuclear membrane from chromatin. The outer nuclear membrane gradually extends into the endoplasmic reticulum. The inner and outer nuclear membranes fuse at some points and form nuclear pores with the aid of large protein complexes. Chromatin is located in the nucleus (karyoplasm). It is present as two forms: euchromatin, which is loosely packaged and active, and heterochromatin, which is densely packaged and inactive. The nucleolus is also located in the karyoplasm and is not surrounded by a membrane. It synthesizes ribosomes and consists of proteins and ribosomal RNA.

F) INCORRECT:

Plectin cross-links various cytoskeletal structures, e.g., intermediate filaments, actin filaments, and microtubules. It is not found in the inner nuclear membrane and has no association with Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome, which is caused by a genetic defect in an intermediate filament that, along with other proteins, forms a dense meshwork inside the inner nuclear membrane.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of easy fatiguability and muscle pain. One month ago, she had an episode of sudden onset right-sided weakness and headache. She has a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures that are treated with antiepileptic drugs and frequent migraines associated with vomiting. Her mother and brother have similar symptoms. Her serum lactate concentration is 3.0 mmol/L (N = 0.5–2.2). Graded exercise testing shows a significantly decreased maximum rate of oxygen consumption. The activity of which of the following metabolic pathways is most likely increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholesterol synthesis takes place in the cytosol, peroxisomes, and smooth endoplasmic reticulum, not in the mitochondria. However, acetyl CoA, which is the precursor for cholesterol synthesis, is produced in the mitochondria. MELAS, a mitochondrial disease, would decrease acetyl CoA production, so it would most likely decrease rather than increase cholesterol synthesis. In addition, the cellular energy deficit caused by mitochondrial diseases decreases energy-dependent processes such as cholesterol synthesis.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyrimidine synthesis takes place in the cytosol, not the mitochondria. However, the cellular deficit that occurs in mitochondrial diseases such as MELAS would most likely decrease rather than increase energy-dependent processes such as pyrimidine synthesis. Pyrimidine synthesis would be increased in malignant cells (e.g., leukemia cells).

C) INCORRECT:

MELAS is typically caused by a defect in a gene coding for mitochondrial tRNA. This defect would decrease rather than increase mitochondrial protein synthesis. In addition, the cellular energy deficit caused by mitochondrial diseases decreases energy-dependent processes such as protein synthesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oxidative phosphorylation takes place in the mitochondria. In MELAS syndrome, mutations of mitochondrial DNA cause respiratory chain defects, resulting in decreased rather than increased oxidative phosphorylation. This is evident from the significantly decreased maximum VO2 in this patient.
Image Description:

A mitochondrion (bottom left, cross section) and its most important functions: Mitochondria are cell organelles made up of a smooth outer membrane, an inner membrane with an increased surface area as a result of folds (cristae), and the matrix, which harbors mitochondrial DNA and ribosomes and is the site of numerous metabolic processes.

Upper left: One of the most important functions of the mitochondria is supplying energy through the electron transport chain, which is integrated into the inner mitochondrial membrane. The phospholipid cardiolipin enables the close arrangement of individual complexes of the electron transport chain.

Upper right: The outer membrane is rich in pores and therefore permeable to numerous substances, whereas the inner membrane can only be permeated via specific transporters.

Bottom right: Proteins must be unfolded before transport in and out of the mitochondrion. Translocases of the inner and outer membranes (TIM and TOM) transport unfolded proteins across the membranes.

E) CORRECT:

MELAS syndrome is typically caused by a defect in genes coding for mitochondrial tRNA. This defect would decrease the synthesis of mitochondrial proteins, including enzymes of the citric acid cycle and mitochondrial respiratory chain, which are responsible for the majority of cellular ATP generation (via aerobic metabolism). In response to a lack of ATP and intermediates of the citric acid cycle (e.g., citrate), enzymes involved in glycolysis (a cytosolic process), such as phosphofructokinase-1, are upregulated. Glycolysis and the anaerobic metabolism of pyruvate generated via glycolysis then serve as the primary sources of ATP. Increased anaerobic metabolism of pyruvate to lactate is also responsible for the lactic acidosis seen in MELAS. ATP deficiency impairs the functioning of tissues that are highly energy-dependent (e.g., neurons, myocytes). Other processes that take place partly or completely in the mitochondria, such as fatty acid β-oxidation, ketogenesis, and the urea cycle, are also impaired. Decreased urea cycle activity and the lack of ketone bodies (an energy source for the brain) further contribute to encephalopathy in MELAS.

A muscle cell biopsy in patients with mitochondrial diseases, such as MELAS, usually shows cytosolic lipid accumulation (due to impaired fatty acid β-oxidation) and a ragged-red fiber appearance.
Image Description:

Glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm and is the metabolic pathway in which glucose is broken down into two pyruvate molecules, generating two molecules of ATP in the process (four ATP generated minus two ATP consumed). In the first phase of glycolysis, ATP (energy) is consumed. In the second and third phases, ATP and reducing equivalents (NADH) are generated.

Black boxes: reactants/products
Blue text: enzymes
Green text: electron carriers (NAD+, NADH+H+) or nucleotides (ATP, ADP) involved in energy consumption and production
Red text: energy (ATP) that is consumed (-) or produced (+) and reducing equivalents (NADH+H+) of each phase

F) INCORRECT:

Beta-oxidation, a mitochondrial process that converts fatty acids into acetyl CoA, serves as an alternative energy source and would be increased in conditions associated with impaired glycolysis or glycogenolysis (e.g., von Gierke disease). Mitochondrial diseases, such as MELAS, result in decreased rather than increased β-oxidation, and characteristically causes the accumulation of fatty acids in the cytosol.
Image Description:

Beta-oxidation of even-numbered fatty acids requires four enzymatic reactions, eventually yielding acyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA through cleavage of two carbons per cycle. This process is nearly identical in mitochondria and peroxisomes, except for some minor differences.

In peroxisomes, FADH2, which is generated during the first reaction, cannot undergo conversion to FAD through the respiratory chain but has to transfer its electrons onto oxygen. This reaction yields H2O2, which will subsequently be broken down into water and oxygen.

Moreover, beta-oxidation in peroxisomes does not allow for complete breakdown of fatty acids into acetyl-CoA. Instead, carbon groups may only be cleaved off up to a chain length of at least eight remaining carbon atoms (octanyl-CoA). These fatty acids are then released into the cytosol and transferred to the mitochondria for complete breakdown. Acetyl-CoA generated in peroxisomes is also released into the cytosol to be used as substrate for other reactions, e.g., the mitochondrial citrate cycle.
questions.hint: Myopathy (e.g., fatigue, muscle pain), encephalopathy (e.g., seizures, headaches, vomiting), increased lactate levels, and stroke-like-episodes (e.g., sudden onset right-sided weakness) suggest MELAS syndrome, a hereditary mitochondrial disease. The presence of symptoms in this patient's mother and brother is consistent with mitochondrial inheritance.
